caseCohort.detectionMethod: This meta-analysis included 5 studies that genotyped individuals for WDR36 variants

controlCohort.detectionMethod: This meta-analysis included 5 studies that genotyped individuals for WDR36 variants

dc:source.dc:abstract: The association of the WDR36 gene with glaucoma has been controversial in the literature. We therefore conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to assess the association of all reported common polymorphisms in WDR36 with primary open angle glaucoma (POAG) and its subtypes: high tension glaucoma (HTG) and normal tension glaucoma (NTG).
dc:source.dc:creator: Liu K
dc:source.dc:title: Association of WDR36 polymorphisms with primary open angle glaucoma: A systematic review and meta-analysis.

evidence.dc:description: The meta analysis studied 5 SNPs in WDR36 for association with primary open angle glaucoma, high-tension glaucoma and normal-tension glaucoma: I264V, V727V, IVS5+30C>T, IVS16-30A>G, IVS3-113G>A. No significant association of any of the SNPs with POAG, HTG or NTG was reported in the meta analysis. For the variants, I264V: pooled-OR of 1.09 (95% CI: 0.94–1.28, P = .25, I2 = 0) and IVS5+30C>T: pooled-OR of 0.99 (95% CI: 0.71–1.39, P = .97, I2 = 77%). The authors note, "existing data in the literature do not support a significant role of WDR36 in the genetic susceptibility of POAG or its subtypes"

dc:source.dc:abstract: To determine the distribution of WDR36 sequence variants in a cohort of patients with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) in the United States.
dc:source.dc:creator: Hauser MA
dc:source.dc:title: Distribution of WDR36 DNA sequence variants in patients with primary open-angle glaucoma.

evidence.dc:description:
Of the 118 probands from families with at least two members affected by POAG, 6 probands from juvenile-onset POAG families, and 108 control individuals
, 17% of POAG patients and 4% of control subjects. No statistical significance was noted for any variant. Authors note that "abnormalities in WDR36 alone are not sufficient to cause POAG…WDR36 may be a glaucoma modifier gene."

dc:source.dc:abstract: Mutations in WDR36 were recently reported in patients with adult-onset primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). In this study, the prevalence of WDR36 variants was investigated in patients with glaucoma who were of German descent with diverse age of onset and intraocular pressure levels.
dc:source.dc:creator: Pasutto F
dc:source.dc:title: Profiling of WDR36 missense variants in German patients with glaucoma.

evidence.dc:description: 8 variants in 15 patients (12 with high IOP and 3 with low IOP) were determined to be disease-causing; however no functional evidence is available to score the evidence.

dc:source.dc:abstract: To determine the distribution of WD repeat domain 36 (WDR36) sequence variants in Chinese patients with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG).
dc:source.dc:creator: Fan BJ
dc:source.dc:title: Different WDR36 mutation pattern in Chinese patients with primary open-angle glaucoma.

evidence.dc:description: Authors note "WDR36 associated with sporadic HTG but not with NTG or JOAG. Results suggest a different mutation pattern of WDR36 in the Chinese population from other ethnic populations". While this study notes a significant association of the IVS5+30C>T variant with HTG, no significance was reported in the meta analysis that included this study.

caseCohort.detectionMethod: 23 exons and flanking introns of the WDR36 gene were screened by SOLiD NGS sequencing

controlCohort.detectionMethod: 23 exons and flanking introns of the WDR36 gene were screened by SOLiD NGS sequencing

dc:source.dc:abstract: Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is one of the most important disease in ophthalmology with high prevalence and risk of irreversible blindness. If diagnosed before the age of 35, it is usually categorized as juvenile open-angle glaucoma (JOAG). The
dc:source.dc:creator: Su HA
dc:source.dc:title: An Application of NGS for

evidence.dc:description: c.1964+2910T>C variant was observed in cases and controls, but the difference was statistically significant. c.1494+1111G>T (p = 0.011) and c.710+30C>T (noted risk factor in HTG; p = 0.268) had significantly higher frequency in cases vs. controls. A novel variant, c.460-650A>G, expected to impact splicing was identified only in cases; however, no functional evidence is available to confirm the impact of the variant. In conclusion, authors note that "WDR36 is only a subordinate factor playing a role of modifier in POAG, without consistency among races or populations".

caseCohort.detectionMethod: 10 SNPs across the WDR36 gene genotyped by PCR-RFLP. In addition, sequencing of exon 5 did not reveal any disease-causing variants.

controlCohort.detectionMethod: 10 SNPs across the WDR36 gene genotyped by PCR-RFLP. In addition, sequencing of exon 5 did not reveal any disease-causing variants.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Glaucoma is a heterogeneous group of optic neuropathies with a complex genetic basis. To date, only the following four genes have been identified: viz. myocilin (MYOC), optineurin (OPTN), WD repeat domain 36 (WDR36), and neurotrophin 4 (NTF4). However, there are conflicting reports regarding the involvement of WDR36 in the pathogenesis of primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG). In the Asian population, mutations in WDR36 appear to play a minor role in POAG pathogenesis but polymorphic variants have been found to be associated with POAG, especially in patients with high tension glaucoma (HTG). The purpose of this study is to determine the role of WDR36 in East Indian POAG patients. To date, no other studies have yet examined this role.
dc:source.dc:creator: Mookherjee S
dc:source.dc:title: WDR36 variants in East Indian primary open-angle glaucoma patients.

evidence.dc:description: The SNP c.710+30C>T was found to be marginally associates with POAG, but when the case cohort was divided into two groups (HTG and non-HTG), the variant was strongly associated with HTG; OR=1.216; 95% CI=1.064–2.306; p=0.002. No score is awarded for this individual study as the meta analysis that included this study found no statistical significance for any WDR36 variants in association with POAG.
Authors show using northern blot that WDR36 is expressed in ocular and extra-ocular tissues.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Glaucoma is a leading cause of blindness in virtually every country. Development of an accurate diagnostic test for presymptomatic detection of individuals at risk is an urgent requisition for this condition. Herein, we report mapping of a new adult-onset primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) locus on 5q22.1 (GLC1G) and identification of its defective gene. Mutation screening of seven candidate genes from the GLC1G critical region (approximately 2 Mb between D5S1466 and D5S2051) identified only one significant alteration in the WDR36 (WD40-repeat 36) gene. This mutation (i.e. D658G) was segregated in all affected members of our first GLC1G-linked family but it was absent in 476 normal control chromosomes. Further screening of WDR36 in a total of 130 POAG families revealed 24 DNA variations. Overall, four mutations (N355S, A449T, R529Q and D658G) were identified in 17 (5.02-6.92%) unrelated POAG subjects, 11 with high-pressure and six with low-pressure glaucoma. These mutations were absent in a minimum of 200 normal control chromosomes and, further they were conserved between WDR36 orthologues in mouse, rat, dog, chimp and human. WDR36 is a novel gene with 23 exons, which encodes for 951 amino acids and a protein with multiple G-beta WD40 repeats. By northern blotting, two distinct mRNA transcripts of 5.9 and 2.5 kb were observed in human heart, placenta, liver, skeletal muscle, kidney and pancreas. WDR36 gene expression in lens, iris, sclera, ciliary muscles, ciliary body, trabecular meshwork, retina and optic nerve were established by RT-PCR. In mouse, two transcripts of 3.5 and 2.9 kb showed analogous expression patterns to human. mRNA expressions were detected in 7-, 11-, 15- and 17-day-old developing mouse embryos. In summary, WDR36 is a novel causative gene for adult-onset POAG at the GLC1G locus. Specific ocular expressions and observed mutations are consistent with WDR36 role in etiology of both high- and low-pressure glaucoma.
dc:source.dc:creator: Monemi S
dc:source.dc:title: Identification of a novel adult-onset primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) gene on 5q22.1.

evidence.rdfs:label: Monemi_expression

evidence.dc:description: The evidence is not scored any points as the expression is ubiquitous.
The study does not provide evidence for the function of WDR36 protein.

dc:source.dc:abstract: To investigate the role of multigenic variation in primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) involving the rRNA processing gene WD repeat domain 36 (WDR36).
dc:source.dc:creator: Footz T
dc:source.dc:title: Co-variation of STI1 and WDR36/UTP21 alters cell proliferation in a glaucoma model.

evidence.rdfs:label: Footz_WDR36 modifier

evidence.dc:description: The study assessed the modifier effect of STI1 in the context of WDR36 variation; however, does not provide evidence for the function of WDR36.

Intra-ocular pressure measurement was similar in WT and mutant mice. ~25% reduction in the peripheral retina thickness was observed for del605–607 mice compared with the WT mice. Disruption of synapses between RGC and amacrine cells was observed in del605-607 mice. RGC axon outgrowth was reduced by ∼60%.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is one of the three principal subtypes of glaucoma and among the leading cause of blindness worldwide. POAG is defined by cell death of the retinal ganglion cells (RGCs) and surrounding neuronal cells at higher or normal intraocular pressure (IOP). Coded by one of the three genes responsible for POAG, WD repeat-containing protein 36 (WDR36) has two domains with a similar folding. To address whether WDR36 is functionally important in the retina, we developed four transgenic mice strains overexpressing a wild-type (Wt) and three mutant variants of D606G, deletion of amino acids at positions 605-607 (Del605-607) and at 601-640 (Del601-640) equivalent to the location of the D658G mutation observed in POAG patients. A triple amino acid deletion of mouse Wdr36 at positions 605-607 corresponding to the deletion at positions 657-659 in humans developed progressive retinal degeneration at the peripheral retina with normal IOP. RGCs and connecting amacrine cell synapses were affected at the peripheral retina. Axon outgrowth rate of cultured RGC directly isolated from transgenic animal was significantly reduced by the Wdr36 mutation compared with Wt. Molecular modeling of wild and mutant mouse Wdr36 revealed that deletion at positions 605-607 removed three residues and a hydrogen bond, required to stabilize anti-parallel β-sheet of the 6th β-propeller in the second domain. We concluded that WDR36 plays an important functional role in the retina homeostasis and mutation to this gene can cause devastating retinal damage. These data will improve understanding of the functional property of WDR36 in the retina and provide a new animal model for glaucoma therapeutics.
dc:source.dc:creator: Chi ZL
dc:source.dc:title: Mutant WDR36 directly affects axon growth of retinal ganglion cells leading to progressive retinal degeneration in mice.

evidence.rdfs:label: Chi_Wdr36 mouse

evidence.dc:description: Mice with WDR36 variants do not show a glaucoma phenotype. Authors note the their results suggest an essential role for Wdr36 in the mouse retina. The evidence is not scored as the causal role of WDR36 variants in humans is not clearly established.

The only clear difference observed between wrd36 morphants and wdr36 mutants was that the phenotypes showed slightly earlier in development when using MOs. Loss of Wdr36 resulted in small head and eye phenotypes with progressive degeneration of the lens development. Gross phenotype of 6 dpf wdr36 mutants included small head and eye phenotypes, along with defects in gut development. Inflated swim bladder was absent. Lens opacity was also observed with incident light illumination of the eye. Mutants also showed large, dysmorphic nucleolus, and disruption of nucleolus led to activation of the p53 stress–response pathway.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a genetically complex neuropathy that affects retinal ganglion cells and is a leading cause of blindness worldwide. WDR36, a gene of unknown function, was recently identified as causative for POAG at locus GLC1G. Subsequent studies found disease-associated variants in control populations, leaving the role of WDR36 in this disease unclear. To address this issue, we determined the function of WDR36. We studied Wdr36 in zebrafish and found it is the functional homolog of yeast Utp21. Utp21 is cell essential and functions in the nucleolar processing of 18S rRNA, which is required for ribosome biogenesis. Evidence for functional homology comes from sequence alignment, ubiquitous expression, sub-cellular localization to the nucleolus and loss-of-function phenotypes that include defects in 18S rRNA processing and abnormal nucleolar morphology. Additionally, we show that loss of Wdr36 function leads to an activation of the p53 stress-response pathway, suggesting that co-inheritance of defects in p53 pathway genes may influence the impact of WDR36 variants on POAG. Although these results overall do not provide evidence for or against a role of WDR36 in POAG, they do provide important baseline information for future studies.
dc:source.dc:creator: Skarie JM
dc:source.dc:title: The primary open-angle glaucoma gene WDR36 functions in ribosomal RNA processing and interacts with the p53 stress-response pathway.

evidence.rdfs:label: Skarie_Zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: The zebrafish model is noted to show a non-specific eye phenotype. In addition, the causal nature of WDR36 variants in human patients with glaucoma is not established. The evidence is not scored.

dc:description:
WDR36 was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant primary open angle glaucoma G in 2005 (Monemi et al., 2005, PMID: 15677485). The study reported linkage to WDR36 in 7 families with primary open angle glaucoma and identifed four variants that were predicted to be disease causing. However, the variants are not supported by functional evidence -- they are found at relatively high population frequencies in gnomAD. 

This gene-disease association has been studied in several case-control studies (PMID: 28658128, 29104481, 22025897, 18172102, 16723468, 19347049, 29540704, 17353431, 28282485, 19875670, 16876519); however, statistical significance was not reached in most. A meta-analysis (Liu et al, 2017; PMID: 28658128) including 5 individual studies reported no statistically significant association of WDR36 variants with primary open angle glaucoma.  

WDR36 is expressed ubiquitously, including th eye (PMID: 15677485). The function of WDR36 is not clearly understood, but animal studies suggest a role in eye development. Zebrafish and mouse models show head and eye phenotypes (PMID: 20631153, 18469340); however, they are non-specific and do not support the role of WDR36 variation in glaucoma. With an unclear role for this gene in glaucoma, it is thought to have a modifier effect in disease (PMID: 29104481). 

In summary, the evidence supporting the relationship between WDR36 and autosomal dominant primary open angle glaucoma has been disputed and no valid evidence remains to support the claim. More evidence is needed to either support or entirely refute the role WDR36 plays in glaucoma, but based on the evidence avaialble at this time, the gene is disputed as a monogenic cause of glaucoma. 
The causal role of WDR36 variants in human disease is not clearly established. No human patients with glaucoma are reported in the literature to carry pathogenic/likely pathogenic variants in WDR36. Case-control studies do not show enrichment of variants in cases vs controls and a meta analysis revealed no statistical significance in the association of WDR36 variants with glaucoma. While studies in animal models show that WDR36 may have a functional role in eye development, none of the models develop the expected glaucoma phenotype. Based on these observations, the WDR36-primary open angle glaucoma gene-disease relationship is disputed.
